beat: Once the player encounters Mitch, the anxious lumberjack, he will plead with the newly arrived player in the square to investigate the bloodstains. Mitch will suggest that the Wizard is involved, but very dangerous.
session_summary:
Intro: The last sliver of sun dipped below the horizon, casting long, skeletal shadows from the buildings that ring the town square. A persistent drizzle had begun, slicking the cobblestones and reflecting the flickering gaslights in distorted pools. The air smelled of wet wood, brine from the nearby harbor, and something else… something vaguely metallic and unsettling. Most of the townsfolk huddled near the Bronze Fountain, their faces etched with a quiet sorrow. Conversations were muted, punctuated by the rhythmic splash of water and the mournful strumming of Jorin, the street performer, who played a melancholic tune on his lute. He seemed oblivious to the tension, lost in his music, but even his notes felt heavy, laden with the unspoken dread. You’ve arrived in Oakhaven seeking answers, a newcomer drawn by whispers of a strange affliction, and the unsettling quiet of a town grappling with a mystery. A few townsfolk glance at you with wary eyes, their expressions unreadable, before returning to their somber reflections. The Town Crier, Jessa, has just finished his rounds, his voice a strained monotone, repeating the same unsettling news: “Bloodstains… found throughout the town… no missing persons… investigation ongoing…” He doesn’t elaborate, but the implication hangs heavy in the air. As you observe, a figure approaches you – Mitch, a lumberjack, his face pale and slick with sweat, his hands nervously twisting a small, worn wooden carving. He seems agitated, his gaze darting around the square as if searching for something, or someone.
Recap: You turn your attention to the copper cup sitting on the edge of the Bronze Fountain. It’s a simple thing, really – a deep, slightly tarnished bowl, the metal cool beneath your fingertips. Years of use have worn it smooth in places, leaving a network of tiny scratches and imperfections. The color is a muted, almost bruised, brown, but there’s something else… a faint, unnatural sheen to the surface, like oil clinging to water, though there's no visible residue. A small, dark stain, almost black, is etched into the bottom of the cup, partially obscured by the grime. It’s difficult to tell exactly what it is, but it seems… fresh. You notice a subtle metallic scent emanating from the cup, stronger than the rain or the damp air. Mitch, who has been watching you with a troubled expression, shifts uneasily. "Don't touch that," he whispers, his voice strained. “It’s bad luck.” He glances nervously at the Town Crier, Jessa, who is currently making his rounds, seemingly oblivious to your actions.

i want to explore the copper cup

You turn your attention to the copper cup sitting on the edge of the Bronze Fountain. It’s a simple thing, really – a deep, slightly tarnished bowl, the metal cool beneath your fingertips. Years of use have worn it smooth in places, leaving a network of tiny scratches and imperfections. The color is a muted, almost bruised, brown, but there’s something else… a faint, unnatural sheen to the surface, like oil clinging to water, though there's no visible residue. A small, dark stain, almost black, is etched into the bottom of the cup, partially obscured by the grime. It’s difficult to tell exactly what it is, but it seems… fresh. You notice a subtle metallic scent emanating from the cup, stronger than the rain or the damp air. Mitch, who has been watching you with a troubled expression, shifts uneasily. "Don't touch that," he whispers, his voice strained. “It’s bad luck.” He glances nervously at the Town Crier, Jessa, who is currently making his rounds, seemingly oblivious to your actions.
